days.title: Arrival in Santiago & Maipo Valley Reconnaissance
days.description: Touching down in the forearc basin of the Central Andes. Traveled southeast into the Maipo Valley to observe the transition from the sedimentary valley floor to the igneous Andean foothills.

images.caption: Figure 1.1: The Santiago basin skyline with the snow-capped Andes rising in the background.
Figure 1.2: Close-up of fluvial conglomerate deposits along the Maipo River banks.

geoNote.title: Andean Orogeny
geoNote.text: Evidence of rapid tectonic uplift is visible in the deeply incised river valleys. The clasts in the conglomerate are predominantly volcanic, indicating high-energy transport from the volcanic arc.

days.title: San Cristobal Igneous Complex
days.description: Hiked the hill to observe the intrusive igneous formations overlooking the basin.

images.caption: Figure 1.1: The Santiago basin skyline with the snow-capped Andes rising in the background.
Figure 1.2: Close-up of fluvial conglomerate deposits along the Maipo River banks.

geoNote.title: Intrusive Rock
geoNote.text: The hill is largely composed of quartz monzonite, an igneous rock that cooled slowly underground.

days.title: Maipo Valley Strata
days.description: Witnessed intense folding in the sedimentary layers of the Caj�n del Maipo.

images.caption: Figure 1.1: The Santiago basin skyline with the snow-capped Andes rising in the background.
Figure 1.2: Close-up of fluvial conglomerate deposits along the Maipo River banks.

geoNote.title: Folding
geoNote.text: The 'V' shaped folds in the canyon walls demonstrate the immense lateral pressure of plate convergence.

days.title: Valparaiso Coastal Uplift
days.description: Explored the UNESCO hills. The steep cliffs show evidence of rapid tectonic coastal rise.

images.caption: Figure 1.1: The Santiago basin skyline with the snow-capped Andes rising in the background.
Figure 1.2: Close-up of fluvial conglomerate deposits along the Maipo River banks.

geoNote.title: Tectonic Uplift
geoNote.text: Major seismic events in this region can uplift the shoreline by over a meter in minutes.

days.title: El Yeso Reservoir
days.description: High altitude reservoir surrounded by turquoise water and gypsum-rich soil.

images.caption: Figure 1.1: The Santiago basin skyline with the snow-capped Andes rising in the background.
Figure 1.2: Close-up of fluvial conglomerate deposits along the Maipo River banks.

geoNote.title: Gypsum Deposits
geoNote.text: The 'Yeso' (Gypsum) found here is an evaporite mineral formed in ancient saline basins.

days.title: Transit to Rapa Nui
days.description: Flight across the Pacific to the most isolated volcanic island in the world.

geoNote.title: Hotspot Volcanism
geoNote.text: Rapa Nui formed from three shield volcanoes emerging from the seafloor over a mantle hotspot.

days.title: Rano Raraku Quarry
days.description: The birthplace of the Moai. Carved directly into the volcanic crater walls.

geoNote.title: Volcanic Tuff
geoNote.text: Tuff is lithified volcanic ash. It is soft enough to carve with basalt tools but hardens over time.

days.title: Orongo & Rano Kau
days.description: The dramatic caldera of Rano Kau shows beautiful freshwater lake stratigraphy.

geoNote.title: Caldera Formation
geoNote.text: A caldera forms when a volcano collapses into itself after emptying its magma chamber.

days.title: Ahu Akivi Caves
days.description: Explored subterranean lava tubes created by ancient flowing magma.

geoNote.title: Lava Tubes
geoNote.text: Caves formed when the outer crust of a lava flow hardened while the molten center kept moving.

days.title: Anakena Beach
days.description: White coral sand contrasting with dark basaltic rocks.

geoNote.title: Coral Sand
geoNote.text: Unlike the volcanic rocks of the island, this sand is biogenic, formed from crushed coral and shells.

days.title: Mainland Return
days.description: Return to Santiago. Evening reflection on the island's volcanic cycle.

images.caption: Figure 12.1: Overview of the Tatio basin showing steam discharge at 06:00.
Figure 12.2: Close-up of siliceous sinter terraces showing active precipitation.

days.title: Patagonia: Punta Arenas
days.description: Flying south to the edge of the continent. Entering the realm of glaciers.

geoNote.title: Glacial Moraines
geoNote.text: The landscape here is shaped by glacial till�unsorted sediment dropped by retreating ice sheets.

days.title: Torres del Paine
days.description: First view of the granite massifs. A masterpiece of intrusive geology.

geoNote.title: Laccoliths
geoNote.text: The 'Torres' are granite laccoliths that intruded into sedimentary rock 12 million years ago.

days.title: Grey Glacier Hike
days.description: Walking beside the massive Southern Patagonian Ice Field.

geoNote.title: Glacial Erosion
geoNote.text: Glaciers act like giant sandpaper, grinding down solid rock into fine 'rock flour'.

days.title: The French Valley
days.description: Deep in the heart of the granite horns. Witnessed small snow avalanches.

geoNote.title: Exfoliation
geoNote.text: Granite 'peels' in layers due to pressure release as overlying rock is eroded away.

days.title: Departure Preparations
days.description: Final morning in the park before the journey back to Punta Arenas.

days.title: Atacama Extension: Moon Valley
days.description: Transition to the high desert. Salt crusts crunching underfoot.

geoNote.title: Evaporites
geoNote.text: Halite and Gypsum crystals form here because evaporation rates far exceed precipitation.

glossary.definition: One tectonic plate sliding beneath another.
Rock formed from compacted volcanic ash.
An igneous intrusion that has forced apart two layers of sedimentary rock.
A large volcanic crater formed by a major eruption leading to the collapse of the mouth of the volcano.
